name: React by Namastedev
description: Comprehensive React.js course by namastedev covering fundamentals to advanced concepts including hooks, state management, testing, and real-world project development

topics.name: Episode 1: Inception - Introduction to React
topics.description: Introduction to React, setting up development environment, understanding the React ecosystem
learningTip: React is a library, not a framework - understand the difference
Component-based thinking: break UI into reusable pieces
Declarative vs Imperative: describe WHAT you want, not HOW
Virtual DOM is React's performance secret - it minimizes real DOM updates
mustNotMiss: React creates a virtual representation of the DOM in memory
Reconciliation: React compares virtual DOM with real DOM to find minimal changes
npm init creates package.json, npx runs packages without installing globally
CDN links for quick prototyping: react.development.js and react-dom.development.js

topics.name: Episode 2: Igniting our App - Build Tools & Bundlers
topics.description: Understanding build tools, bundlers like Parcel/Webpack, and setting up a React project
learningTip: Bundlers (Parcel/Webpack) transform your code for production
Dev server provides hot module replacement for instant feedback
package.json vs package-lock.json: specs vs exact versions
node_modules is huge - always .gitignore it
mustNotMiss: npm install creates node_modules and package-lock.json
Parcel: zero-config bundler, just 'npx parcel index.html'
devDependencies vs dependencies: dev tools vs production code
npx parcel build index.html creates production bundle

topics.name: Episode 3: Laying the Foundation - JSX & Components
topics.description: Deep dive into JSX, creating React components, and understanding the virtual DOM
learningTip: JSX is syntactic sugar for React.createElement() calls
JSX looks like HTML but has key differences (className, htmlFor)
Components must return a single root element (use Fragment if needed)
Functional components are just functions that return JSX
mustNotMiss: JSX compiles to React.createElement(type, props, ...children)
Curly braces {} embed JavaScript expressions in JSX
Component names MUST start with uppercase (MyComponent, not myComponent)
React.Fragment or <></> wraps multiple elements without extra DOM nodes

topics.name: Episode 4: Talk is Cheap, Show Me the Code - Building UI
topics.description: Building actual UI components, props, and creating reusable components
learningTip: Props flow down from parent to child (unidirectional data flow)
Props are read-only - never modify props directly
Destructuring props: const { name, age } = props or ({name, age})
Component composition: build complex UIs from simple components
mustNotMiss:
Props: const Card = (props) =>
{props.title}

Destructured: const Card = ({title, desc}) =>
{title}
key prop is required when rendering lists: arr.map(item => <Card key={item.id}/>)
key must be unique among siblings and stable (not index if list changes)

topics.name: Episode 5: Let's Get Hooked - React Hooks Introduction
topics.description: Introduction to React Hooks, useState, and functional component state management
learningTip: useState returns [value, setter] - always destructure both
State updates trigger re-renders - this is React's reactivity
Never mutate state directly: use setter function
Previous state: setCount(prev => prev + 1) for updates based on current value
mustNotMiss: const [count, setCount] = useState(0) - 0 is initial value
setCount(5) replaces, setCount(prev => prev + 1) updates based on previous
Hooks must be called at top level - not inside loops, conditions, or nested functions
Hooks can only be called in functional components or custom hooks

topics.name: Episode 6: Exploring the World - API Integration
topics.description: Making API calls, useEffect hook, handling asynchronous operations, and CORS
learningTip: useEffect handles side effects: API calls, subscriptions, DOM changes
Dependency array controls when effect runs: [], [deps], or nothing
async/await works inside useEffect with IIFE pattern
Always handle loading and error states for better UX
mustNotMiss: useEffect(() => { fetchData() }, []) - runs once on mount
useEffect(() => { ... }, [dep]) - runs when dep changes
Return cleanup function: useEffect(() => { return () => cleanup() }, [])
fetch().then().catch() or async IIFE: (async () => { await fetch() })()

topics.name: Episode 6.1 & 6.2: API Issues Resolution
topics.description: Resolving Swiggy API issues and CORS plugin problems
learningTip: CORS errors happen when browser blocks cross-origin requests
CORS is a browser security feature, not a server issue
Proxy during development avoids CORS without backend changes
Production: configure server CORS headers properly
mustNotMiss: CORS error: 'Access to fetch has been blocked by CORS policy'
Dev solution: browser extension or dev server proxy
Production: server must send Access-Control-Allow-Origin header
API mocking with json-server for development and testing

topics.name: Episode 7: Finding the Path - React Router
topics.description: Implementing client-side routing with React Router
learningTip: React Router enables SPA routing without page reloads
BrowserRouter wraps your app, Routes contains Route components
Link replaces <a> for navigation without page reload
useParams() gets URL parameters, useNavigate() for programmatic navigation
mustNotMiss: createBrowserRouter() with createRoutesFromElements() is the modern API
<Route path='/user/:id' element={<User/>}/> - :id is dynamic parameter
const {id} = useParams() gets the dynamic segment
<Outlet/> renders child routes in parent component

topics.name: Episode 8: Let's Get Classy - Class Components
topics.description: Understanding class components, lifecycle methods, and component patterns
learningTip: Class components are older but still important to understand
Lifecycle methods replaced by useEffect in functional components
this.state and this.setState for state management
Know class components for legacy code maintenance
mustNotMiss: constructor(props) { super(props); this.state = {} }
componentDidMount() ≈ useEffect(() => {}, [])
componentDidUpdate() ≈ useEffect(() => {}, [deps])
componentWillUnmount() ≈ useEffect cleanup function

topics.name: Episode 9: Optimizing our App - Performance
topics.description: Performance optimization techniques, lazy loading, and code splitting
learningTip: React.lazy() enables code splitting for smaller initial bundles
Suspense provides fallback UI while lazy components load
Code splitting reduces initial load time significantly
Split by route: each route loads only when accessed
mustNotMiss: const LazyComponent = React.lazy(() => import('./Component'))
<Suspense fallback={<Loading/>}><LazyComponent/></Suspense>
Dynamic imports with import() return Promises
Analyze bundle with webpack-bundle-analyzer or Parcel's --detailed-report

topics.name: Episode 10: Jo Dikhta Hai, Vo Bikta Hai - Styling
topics.description: Styling React applications, CSS-in-JS, and UI libraries
learningTip: Multiple CSS-in-JS approaches: styled-components, CSS Modules, Tailwind
CSS Modules scope styles locally to avoid global conflicts
Tailwind provides utility classes for rapid styling
Choose based on team preference and project needs
mustNotMiss: CSS Modules: import styles from './Component.module.css'
Styled-components: const Button = styled.button`color: blue;`
Tailwind: className='bg-blue-500 text-white p-4 rounded'
Inline styles: style={{backgroundColor: 'blue'}} - camelCase properties

topics.name: Episode 11: Data is the New Oil - State Management
topics.description: Advanced state management patterns, prop drilling solutions, and context API
learningTip: Context API solves prop drilling for global state
Create context, provide value, consume with useContext
Context re-renders all consumers when value changes
For complex state, consider Redux or Zustand
mustNotMiss: const MyContext = React.createContext(defaultValue)
<MyContext.Provider value={data}>{children}</MyContext.Provider>
const value = useContext(MyContext) in consumer component
Split contexts by concern to minimize unnecessary re-renders

topics.name: Episode 12: Let's Build Our Store - Redux
topics.description: Introduction to Redux, Redux Toolkit, and state management with Redux
learningTip: Redux: single source of truth for predictable state
Actions describe what happened, reducers update state
Redux Toolkit simplifies Redux with less boilerplate
createSlice combines actions and reducers
mustNotMiss: configureStore({ reducer: { cart: cartReducer } })
createSlice({ name, initialState, reducers: {} })
useSelector(state => state.cart.items) reads state
useDispatch() returns dispatch function for actions

topics.name: Episode 13: Time for Test - Testing in React
topics.description: Testing React applications, Jest, React Testing Library, and test-driven development
learningTip: Testing gives confidence when refactoring code
React Testing Library tests behavior, not implementation
Test what users see and do, not internal component logic
Jest provides test runner and assertions
mustNotMiss: render(<Component/>) renders component for testing
screen.getByText('Hello') finds element by text
screen.getByRole('button') finds by accessibility role
fireEvent.click() or userEvent.click() simulates user actions

topics.name: Episode 14: NetflixGPT - The Beginning
topics.description: Starting a complex project, project architecture, and advanced React patterns
learningTip: Understand the concept thoroughly before moving on
Practice by building small projects with each concept
Read official React documentation for authoritative guidance
Break complex problems into smaller, manageable pieces
mustNotMiss: React components should be pure - same inputs, same output
State updates are asynchronous and batched
Always use key prop when rendering lists
Keep components small and focused on single responsibility

topics.name: Episode 15: NetflixGPT - Building the Core
topics.description: Building core features, API integration, and complex state management
learningTip: Understand the concept thoroughly before moving on
Practice by building small projects with each concept
Read official React documentation for authoritative guidance
Break complex problems into smaller, manageable pieces
mustNotMiss: React components should be pure - same inputs, same output
